div.p: B63/4520, unit 749, VPRS 1189/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.
MS written by Ernst Heyne and signed by M. Melbourne botan. Gardens

I have the honor to inform you, that the elaboration of the second volume of the Universal work on Australian plants by G. Bentham Esq., the President of the Linnean Society of London has been commenced under my aid and that the first volume for which a subsidy of £100 was granted by the Victorian Government, has been issued in London and that a share of the copies for the Government may be expected to arrive within the next months. A subsidy of £100 understood to be continued having been made towards the publication of the first Volume out of the Vote for publishing works on Australian plants, I would have recommended to Your favorable consideration, that a remittance for the second Volume might be effected out of the same vote, had not this item been reduced from £320 to £250. Hence it would be necessary to discontinue for the remainder of the year the labors on illustrating the plants of Victoria by our local artist,
who is this?
if the second remittance had to be defrayed out of the reduced vote, and I ventured therefore to solicit from Your honorable predecessor in a letter dated April 29th 1863,
x-ref needed.
that a special provision might be granted on the supplementary estimates for the continuation of Mr Bentham's work, especially as the Governments of New South Wales, South Australia and Queensland have also given a generous support to Mr Benthams publication by a special grant for each volume.

Mr O'Shannassy and Mr Haines viewed my proposition most favorably and placed therefore the sum of £100 on the Supplem. Estimates for this year. Now I would beg to solicit, that you will be pleased to confirm the favor of Your honorable predecessor and I may be allowed to add, that neither President Bentham nor myself derive any monetary advantage whatsoever from this work, but that the subsidies from the Governments of the Australian Colonies have merely been sought to allow the London publisher to issue the volumes at so low a price, as to render the work accessible also to the unwealthy classes. In recommendation of the work, it may be sufficient to remark, that President Bentham the most illustrious of all living describing Botanists, wishes to crown labors, commenced before I was born, and extended now over more than 40 years, with the elucidation of the flora of this great continent, and that for this purpose not only the vast collections of Australian plants, in Great Britain, accumulated since Sir Jos. Banks's visit to the Australian shores in Cooks first voyage are consulted, but also that the apparently still larger collections, which are gathered and preserved in the scientific branch of this establishment will be fully consulted.
